What is Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana (PMFBY)?
Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana (PMFBY) is a Government Scheme that provides crop insurance protection to farmers when notified crops are damaged due to natural calamities.

When was the scheme launched?
The PMFBY scheme was launched on 18th February 2016 by the honorable Prime Minister of India.

What is crop insurance?

Crop insurance is a crucial tool that helps farmers safeguard themselves from financial losses caused by unexpected natural disasters such as hailstorms, droughts, floods, cyclones, heavy rains, diseases, and pests. It provides a safety net for farmers in case of such unforeseen events.

Why farmers should avail crop insurance?

Adverse weather/climatic conditions such as heavy rains, floods, hailstones, cloudbursts, landslide and natural fire etc, can cause significant damage to crops, partially or wholly. It can burden you economically and socially. Therefore, it is imperative to have economic and social security with the help of crop insurance so that you are protected from probable crop loss.

What are the provisions under PMFBY/RWBCIS to help farmers?

Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana (PMFBY) provides crop insurance protection to farmers in case of damage to notified crops due to unexpected natural calamities. Notified crops are those identified by State Governments to be covered under crop insurance. Field crops like cereals, pulses, and oilseeds are covered under PMFBY, while horticulture crops such as fruits and vegetables are covered under the Restructured Weather Based Crop Insurance Scheme (RWBCIS). The scheme offers farmers very low premium rates to participate in the insurance scheme.

Where do I get information about PMFBY/RWBCIS?

You can call on toll-free Krishi Rakshak helpline no 14447 or reach out to the nearest Bank Branch/Banking Correspondent, Primary Agriculture Credit Societies (PACS), Common Service Centre (CSC), representative of the insurance company in your area, or the local agriculture office at District/Block level for information and insurance of notified crops. For more details, you can also visit the National Crop Insurance Portal at www.pmfby.gov.in.

Which category of farmers are eligible to enroll under PMFBY?

All farmers, including tenant farmers and sharecroppers cultivating notified crops in notified areas, are eligible for crop insurance. The enrollment has been made voluntary for all farmers, so now farmers can join the scheme as per their willingness.

Which crops are covered under the scheme?

Crops notified by the State Govt in its notification are covered under crops insurance scheme. the State Govt releases this notification at beginning of every season. The scheme includes all food grain, oilseed crops, and annual commercial/annual horticulture crops in both Kharif and Rabi seasons.

What are the premium rates to be paid by the farmers for enrolment under PMFBY?
The premium rates for enrolment under PMFBY are 2% for Kharif crop, 1.5% for Rabi crops, and up to 5% for horticulture and commercial crops of the sum insured.

What are the enrollment channels open for a farmer to participate in PMFBY/RWBCIS?

Common Service Centers (CSC) are local access facilities that serve rural and remote locations, providing various government e-services including enrollment for schemes like PMFBY/RWBCIS. You can also enrol through the nearest bank branch, primary agriculture cooperative societies, post office, insurance intermediary, or self-enrollment via the web portal-https://www.pmfby.gov.in/farmerLogin.

Can I enroll under PMFBY/RWBCIS if I have savings account/Jan Dhan Account in any bank?
That's correct! All Savings or Jan Dhan Account holding farmers can enroll in the scheme through their respective bank branches.

What is the role of banks in enrolling the Loanee farmers under PMFBY/RWBCIS?

Banks play a crucial role in enrolling Loanee farmers under PMFBY/RWBCIS by ensuring the enrolment of Loanee and other interested farmers, maintaining proper records, encouraging farmers to join the scheme, and timely data entry on the PMFBY portal. It is important for banks to coordinate effectively to avoid duplication and provide necessary support to the farmers.

What is the self-declaration  to be submitted to bank by the existing loanee farmer?

To submit a self-declaration to the bank as an existing loanee farmer who does not wish to be enrolled under the scheme, you can do so by providing a written statement to your serving bank branch, at least 7 days before the cut-off date for enrolment for the respective season. If you do not submit this self-declaration, the premium amount for the notified crops will be deducted from your account by the bank.

What is the cut-off date for enrolment under PMFBY/RWBCIS?
General enrolment cut-offs for Kharif season is 15-31 July and for Rabi season it is 15-30 December. it may vary from state to state depending on crop cultivation cycle.

To enrol in the crop insurance scheme, you will need to provide certain mandatory documents. These include your Land Rights Documents such as Record of Right (RoR) and Land Possession Certificate (LPC), an updated Aadhar Card, and your Bank Passbook (First Page with details of bank accounts).

What are the recent changes made in Revamped PMFBY/RWBCIS for farmer participation?

Under the revamped scheme, farmers can now voluntarily enroll in the Revamped PMFBY/RWBCIS. Loanee farmers who do not wish to be part of the scheme can choose to Opt Out by submitting a self-declaration to their bank branch. Additionally, all Savings or Jan Dhan Account holding farmers are eligible to participate by enrolling through their respective bank branches. It's important for farmers to inform the bank branches if they wish to participate in the scheme while renewing or applying for a Kisan Credit Card. Farmers also have the flexibility to change the insured crop name up to 2 working days before the cut-off date for enrollment. The premium rates for the scheme remain the same as before.

All the proposed changes are effective from kharif 2020 season.Remember, these changes are aimed at improving the effectiveness of the scheme for farmers across the country.

How sum insured will be calculated after recent changes announced in the scheme?

The sum insured will be calculated based on various options provided to State Governments, such as Scale of Finance determined by District Level Technical Committee, District level value of Notional Average Yield x Minimum Support Price for any district-crop combination, Farmgate price for crops without MSP, and weighted average market price for the previous season. Each district may choose the most suitable method for their specific crop combinations.

Which are the risks covered under PMFBY/RWBCIS?
Prevented Sowing, Mid – Season Adversity, Localized Calamity, Post – Harvest Loss and Widespread Calamity are the risks covered under PMFBY/RWBCIS.

What is prevented sowing?

Prevented sowing refers to the situation where more than 75% of the crop in the normal sowing area is affected due to adverse seasonal or weather conditions, leading to the inability to sow, plant, or germinate the crops. In such cases, a claim payment of 25% of the sum assured can be made, subject to the State Government issuing a notification regarding this situation.

What is mid-season adversity?

Mid-season adversity refers to various challenges that can affect crop production during the growing period, such as drought, floods, pests, diseases, and natural disasters like storms and cyclones. The government provides risk protection against these adversities to support farmers in case their crop production is significantly reduced. The compensation amount is determined based on the extent of the losses incurred by the farmers.

What are Post-Harvest Losses?

Post-Harvest Losses refer to the yield loss of crops that are harvested and left in the field for drying for up to 2 weeks after harvesting. This loss is assessed against specific risks like Hailstorm, Cyclone, Cyclonic rains, and Unseasonal rains. If there is a crop loss, the insured farmer should inform the relevant authorities within 72 hours, providing details of the insured crop and affected area. The assessment of loss is done on an individual farm basis.
